subject: Management
title: The Sunk Cost Trap
description: A quick, practical guide to The Sunk Cost Trap.

hook.text: A company spent $50M on a failing project. They invested $20M more because quitting felt like waste.

buildup.text: The sunk cost fallacy: past spending shouldn't affect future decisions, but it always does.

discovery.text: Under pressure, this bias intensifies. Admitting failure feels worse when stakes are high.

twist.text: The rational question isn't what have we spent. It's what will we gain going forward.

climax.text: Kill the project. Redirect the $20M. That's not quitting. That's deciding.

punchline.text: What you've spent is gone. Only the future is yours to decide.

quiz.question: Why does the sunk cost fallacy worsen under pressure?
options: Admitting failure feels worse when stakes are high
Past investments become more valuable during crises
Pressure makes people forget what was spent
